string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Main Project - How to create accessible material 3rd version
Principles of UD – Flexibility In Use
Principles of UD – Tolerance For Error
Make Sure Tags Or Tools Are Supported
Be Patient with Experts and Users

search.slidetext: big ideaaccessibility training
introduction

introduction to the guides welcome and your guides will be lily, marilyn, and andrew. they will be with you throughout this lesson today. click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction click for introduction
what is accessibility accessible means a person with a disability can acquire, engage, and enjoy the same services as a person without a disability.
it’s the law accessibility includes requirements that are technical and related to the underlying code rather than the visual appearance.
rationale for accessible materials individuals with disabilities can access information contained in materials.
question: how comfortable are you with accessibility knowledge? directions: move the slider to indicate your answer on the appropriate face assessment #1

question: can you help the chameleon stand out against the background. this is a color contrast accessibility assessment. assessment #2 directions: adjust the dials until you find the correct contrast colors of the chameleon image.
triggering phase
common barriers – visual visual disability is a decreased ability to see that causes problems not fixable by using, glasses or medications.
common barriers - auditory auditory disabilities is the partial or total inability to hear, also known as hearing impairment.
common barriers - physical physical disabilities is a condition that substantially limits one or more basic physical activities in life.
common barriers - cognitive cognitive disabilities affect part of the nervous system and impact how well people understand information.
common barriers - speech speech disabilities include difficulty producing speech that is recognizable by others or by voice recognition software.

icebreaker activity what alternative text would you give to describe this picture to a visually impaired reader? (alternative text helps screen-reading tools describe images to visually impaired readers incase the images don’t load or are turned off in the browser.) take a few minutes to think about it. photographed by: vincent m.a. janssen

icebreaker activity - discussion what alternative text would you give to describe this picture to a visually impaired reader? here are some idea an ornate, medieval staircase with four u-shaped flights staircase in rouen cathedral booksellers staircase in rouen cathedral booksellers staircase in rouen cathedral, an ornate, medieval staircase with four u-shaped flights. photographed by: vincent m.a. janssen

incorrect the correct order is: 1=using color and contrast to improve visibility.; 2=designing pages that can be navigated using only a keyboard. ;3=provide text alternatives for non-text content. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct the correct order is: 1=using color and contrast to improve visibility.; 2=designing pages that can be navigated using only a keyboard. ;3=provide text alternatives for non-text content. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #3 2. 3. 1. using color and contrast to improve visibility. provide text alternatives for non-text content. designing pages that can be navigated using only a keyboard. question: what is the most important method for making web content accessible? directions: drag and drop the answers in an order you think is most important to least important.
allegations that miami university uses inaccessible educational technologies and course materials. disability discrimination lawsuit

incorrect false is the correct answer: certain animations can be distracting and cause dizziness, nausea, headaches, and seizures in people with vestibular and photosensitivity disorders. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct false is the correct answer: certain animations can be distracting and cause dizziness, nausea, headaches, and seizures in people with vestibular and photosensitivity disorders. continue continue continue continue continue continue question: when considering accessibility should you use lots of blinking and animated images and backgrounds when creating your presentations/materials? directions: choose the correct answer. true false assessment #4
population consideration design with your population in mind. dyslexia is one of the greatest learning difficulties facing people.

incorrect answer - text alternatives are used to describe a digital image, this description can be read aloud for individuals using screen readers, in addition when an image doesn’t load proper the text alternative will be visible when the image should be. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct answer - text alternatives are used to describe a digital image, this description can be read aloud for individuals using screen readers, in addition when an image doesn’t load proper the text alternative will be visible when the image should be. continue continue continue continue continue continue question: when you insert an image what type of tag do you need to use to describe the image? directions: fill in your answer in the space provided. assessment #5 type your text here

question - when you insert an image what type of tag do you need to use to describe the image? answer - text alternatives are used to describe a digital image, this description can be read aloud for individuals using screen readers, in addition when an image doesn’t load proper the text alternative will be visible when the image should be. assessment #5 - debrief
exploration phase
guidelines for materials creating materials that are easy to perceive requires a series of considerations.
guidelines for materials #1 use simple language and be mindful of reading levels. use available tools and frameworks to analyze your material
guidelines for materials #2 use headings to organize documents. most applications have pre-built tools to assist with this, use those features.
guidelines for materials #3 use page numbers and table of contents in your material to help in the navigation of information.
guidelines for materials #4 provide alternative descriptions for images as both caption and “alt. texts.”

incorrect answer d: both a & b - add alternative (“alt”) text that describes the image to screen readers, and create a separate version of the page with no images. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct answer d: both a & b - add alternative (“alt”) text that describes the image to screen readers, and create a separate version of the page with no images. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #6 add alternative (“alt”) text that describes the image to screen readers. add alternative (“alt”) text that describes the image to screen readers. add alternative (“alt”) text that describes the image to screen readers. question: how can we make an image accessible to someone who can’t see it? directions: choose the best answer the following question. create a separate version of the page with no images. create a separate version of the page with no images. create a separate version of the page with no images. pictures and photos are visual and should be used all the time. pictures and photos are visual and should be used all the time. pictures and photos are visual and should be used all the time. answer a & b answer a & b answer a & b
guidelines for materials #5 set equations and formulas using equations editors and typesetting.
guidelines for materials #6 check your color palette for contrast to make sure your colors contrast well against one another
guidelines for materials #6a contrast is one of the more common web accessibility issues, but it is also one of the easiest to fix.

incorrect the answers are row 1. _b__ yellow on black; row 2. _a__ black on orange; row 3. _b__ black on green; row 4. _a__ white on purple continue continue continue continue continue continue correct the answers are row 1. _b__ yellow on black; row 2. _a__ black on orange; row 3. _b__ black on green; row 4. _a__ white on purple continue continue continue continue continue continue question: which boxes have the best looking text to background contrast? directions: select the best contrast box in each row assessment #7 row column a column b 1 2 3 4 blue on black blue on black blue on black yellow on black yellow on black yellow on black black on orange black on orange black on orange green on orange green on orange green on orange red on green red on green red on green black on green black on green black on green white on purple white on purple white on purple grey on purple grey on purple grey on purple

incorrect color contrast checker tool, which is available for free online. this tool lets you enter the url of the website you want to test, and it will then generate a report that shows how well the site meets the contrast requirements for people with different types of color vision deficiency. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct color contrast checker tool, which is available for free online. this tool lets you enter the url of the website you want to test, and it will then generate a report that shows how well the site meets the contrast requirements for people with different types of color vision deficiency. continue continue continue continue continue continue question: a way to test your website for color contrast is to use the _____ contrast checker tool, which is available for free online. assessment #8 directions: fill in the blank with the correct answer below. type your text here
guidelines for materials #7 use descriptive links instead of “click here.” links should explain the resource you are linking to.
guidelines for materials #8 only use tables for data when required. determine if using tables or not is the best way to present your information
guidelines for materials #9 create and provide accurate closed-captions and transcripts. there are numerous free or inexpensive options.
guidelines for materials #10 present information in multiple ways and formats such as podcasts or an mp4 machine-read version of the content.
legal issues educational institutions have been presented with legal challenges from us department of education..
creating accessible pdfs scanning analog documents to make them accessible is a challenging process.
basic principles of ud offering multiple content formats and communication channels makes your courses flexible for many disabilities.
principles of ud - equitable use equitable design provides all users the same means of use: identical whenever possible; equivalent when not.
principles of ud – flexibility in use the design accommodates individual preferences and abilities.

incorrect the answer is d. a & b provide choice in methods of use and provide adaptability to the user’s pace continue continue continue continue continue continue correct the answer is d. a & b provide choice in methods of use and provide adaptability to the user’s pace continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #9 provide choice in methods of use. provide choice in methods of use. provide choice in methods of use. question: when designing your material for “flexibility in use” one should? directions: choose the best answer the following question. provide adaptability to the user’s pace provide adaptability to the user’s pace provide adaptability to the user’s pace hand out paper copies and have them read the material hand out paper copies and have them read the material hand out paper copies and have them read the material answer a & b answer a & b answer a & b
principles of ud – simple & intuitive the design use is easy to understand without knowing the user’s experience, knowledge, language skills.
principles of ud – perceptible info the design communicates the correct information regardless of the user’s sensory abilities.
principles of ud – tolerance for error the design minimizes hazards.
principles of ud – physical effort the design can be used efficiently with a minimum of fatigue.

incorrect answer is 1=simple and intuitive user; 2=perceptible information; 3=flexibility in use; 4=physical effort; 5=tolerance for error; 6= equitable use continue continue continue continue continue continue correct answer is 1=simple and intuitive user; 2=perceptible information; 3=flexibility in use; 4=physical effort; 5=tolerance for error; 6= equitable use continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #10 principle of ud drop choice definition directions: drag the principle of ud over to the correct definition equitable use flexibility in use simple and intuitive use perceptible information tolerance for error physical effort size & space 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. use of the design is easy to understand, regardless of the user's experience, knowledge, language skills, or current concentration level. communicates necessary information effectively to the user, regardless of ambient conditions or the user's sensory abilities. accommodates a wide range of individual preferences and abilities. can be used efficiently and comfortably and with a minimum of fatigue. appropriate size and space is provided for approach, reach, manipulation, and use regardless of user's body size, posture, or mobility. minimizes hazards and the adverse consequences of accidental or unintended actions. useful and marketable to people with diverse abilities.
principles of ud – size & space appropriate size and space is provided regardless of the user’s body size, posture, or mobility.
integration phase
case activity - discussion as a new faculty, the school wants to assist in making sure our members follow the accessibility guidelines.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue case activity – choice #1 question: as a new faculty member, do you use “no alt text or alt text” directions: choose a door option for images. alt text no alt text
case activity – choice answer #1 directions: choose a door option for images. do you use “no alt text or alt text” alt text no alt text
case activity - discussion as a new faculty, do you understand enough about alt text, and how much is enough? alt text no alt text

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue case activity – choice #2 alt text no alt text animal cat sleeping cat a cat sleeping on a blanket a cat dozing on a blanket animal on a blanket now that you have decided to use the alt text for your images, how do you know what words to use to describe your picture and how far do you go. directions: drag the words that best describe the picture to the file cabinet to keep and to the trash can to toss.

case activity – choice answer #2 alt text no alt text animal cat sleeping cat a cat sleeping on a blanket a cat dozing on a blanket animal on a blanket the answers are: trash can gets - cat, animal on a blanket, animal and sleeping cat because they are not descriptive enough. file cabinet gets - a cat sleeping on a blanket, or a cat dozing on a blanket because the are descriptive and should be used.

alt text is important because it makes images more accessible to people and search engines. even when they cannot be displayed. if you don’t provide appropriate alt text, people using screen readers can’t get information from images. this unfairly excludes users with visual impairments. which can harm your brand reputation, traffic, and conversion rate. it also prevents you from having legal issues. add alt text to the right kinds of images, be descriptive yet concise, include a keyword or words. also called alt tags and alt descriptions, alt text is the written copy that appears in place of an image on a web page if the image fails to load on a user's screen. this text helps screen-reading tools describe images to visually impaired readers and allows search engines to better crawl and rank your website. case activity – choice #3 image alt text: what it is, how to write it, and why it matters click on the what, how, and why tab to see information. what how why
resolution phase
accessibility answers accessibility is to remove barriers and provide equal opportunities for everyone, regardless of their disabilities.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #13 deaf or hard of hearing people. deaf or hard of hearing people. deaf or hard of hearing people. question: who benefits from captions and transcriptions from audio content? direction: choose the best answer for the question. people in a noisy or quiet environment. people in a noisy or quiet environment. people in a noisy or quiet environment. people with cognitive disabilities who benefit from reading text on screen while listening to it. people with cognitive disabilities who benefit from reading text on screen while listening to it. people with cognitive disabilities who benefit from reading text on screen while listening to it. all of the above. all of the above. all of the above.
remember the context for a screen reader audience, a balance between too little info and too much redundancy should be maintained.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #14 the chemistry syllabus is here. the chemistry syllabus is here. the chemistry syllabus is here. question: which of the following is a good example of clear, descriptive link text? direction: choose the best answer for the question. learn more about our programs. learn more about our programs. learn more about our programs. learn more about our research programs on law and health. learn more about our research programs on law and health. learn more about our research programs on law and health.
make sure tags or tools are supported some accessibility tags & standards have been proposed, but do not have full support in screen readers or browsers..
think about accessibility early consider accessibility at the beginning. it will make your editing time simpler and quicker.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment #15 heading tags aren’t helpful for screen reader users. heading tags aren’t helpful for screen reader users. heading tags aren’t helpful for screen reader users. heading level order doesn’t matter. heading level order doesn’t matter. heading level order doesn’t matter. heading levels should be hierarchical (h1, h2, h3, etc). heading levels should be hierarchical (h1, h2, h3, etc). heading levels should be hierarchical (h1, h2, h3, etc). all of the above. all of the above. all of the above. question: which of the following is true regarding accessible headings? direction: choose the best answer for the question.
be patient with experts and users accessibility is a complex issue that doesn’t have simple answers. experts and users still struggle with best laid plans.
keep up with accessibility developments technology is continuously evolving. this will create new accessibility issues.

quiz set up enter your name in the box below to be used for the quiz you will need to score an 80% or higher in order to pass. anything below that you will need to retake the quiz. type your name here submit submit submit

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue quiz question #1 ensure a high level of contrast between the color of text and the background color. ensure a high level of contrast between the color of text and the background color. ensure a high level of contrast between the color of text and the background color. question: which of the following is a good example of clear, descriptive link text? direction: choose the best answer for the question. create a separate colorful version of the page. create a separate colorful version of the page. create a separate colorful version of the page. vibrant, rich color combinations should be strictly used, no matter what. vibrant, rich color combinations should be strictly used, no matter what. vibrant, rich color combinations should be strictly used, no matter what. all above all above all above

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question: true or false: should i use headings, subheadings, and body text formatting when creating written material? directions: choose the correct answer. quiz question #2 true false

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue quiz question #3 directions: drag the icons to the correct disability description that match visual problems like visual strobe and flashing effect problems, also complete blindness or color blondness or poor eyesight learning difficulties or poor memory difficult to use a keyboards or mouse reading problems, find words difficult auditory problems like deafness and hearing impairments or difficulty to hear well or hear clearly

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue quiz question #4 question: in the principles of wcag, users must be able to ____________ the content and interface. directions: fill in the blank with the correct answer below. type your text here read see understand

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue quiz question #5 export pdfs directly from programs like microsoft word. check for and enable accessibility options in those platforms before exporting. question: when creating successful pdf what should your steps be? directions: drag the numbers onto the definition to indicate sequential order. start with a clean copy of the document (free of markup or margin notes). use a document conversion tool available at your institution to convert documents from one form to another. this includes the ability to convert images to scanned readable text (ocr). set the scanner to a higher resolution/quality when possible. 1 2 3 4

review presentation if you want to review the presentation you can click on the image below or click on continue with current presentation. continue with current presentation continue with current presentation continue with current presentation continue with current presentation continue with current presentation continue with current presentation
conclusion

for those of you who want to learn more about accessibility requirements can visit the following websites. microsoft accessibility training essentials - https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/accessibility/resources?activetab=pivot_1%3aprimaryr5 digital.gov - https://digital.gov/topics/accessibility/ section508.gov - https://www.section508.gov/ ada.gov - https://www.ada.gov/resources/?filters= next steps
thank you for watching

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: The practice of making information, activities, and/or environments sensible, meaningful, and usable for as many people as possible
